fullText: “Liberation” is timely, but it does more than just appeal to resistance-frazzled audiences. NEW YORK — If you’ve watched with growing alarm as art that preserves thorny histories and agitates for social progress has come under attack, bookmark this page and go buy tickets for “Liberation.” The superb and galvanizing new play by Bess Wohl would undoubtedly earn the derisive label “woke” in the most technical sense: It’s about a consciousness-raising group in 1970s Ohio awakening women to everyday oppression. When I first saw the show in April, off-Broadway at Roundabout Theatre Company before this Broadway transfer, I had the peculiar feeling of wishing its subject felt as nostalgic as its impeccably vintage design. There have been periods over the past 50 years when the primary concerns of second-wave feminism have seemed to be long-settled — and now certainly isn’t one. But “Liberation” does more than appeal to resistance-frazzled nerves, an ameliorative quality it shares with last season’s “Good Night, and Good Luck,” the hit George Clooney vehicle about a free press holding the government to account. Wohl’s ensemble drama is a memory play about a social movement, full of arguments that will ring familiar to many. But it’s rooted in vibrant, complex characters who embody the individual stakes entangled behind efforts at solidarity. Yes, “Liberation” flips back to a timely chapter in women’s history. (Mothers, take your friends and daughters, and vice versa.) It’s also an enthralling, emotional knockout and the first must-see play of the season. The audience is greeted by a surrogate for the playwright, played by Susannah Flood, who brings a sunny-sharp ease to the animating question: What went wrong back then, when her mom convened this group, that led us to where we are now? (Wohl’s mother worked at Ms. Magazine, but the playwright notes the story is fictional.) Boundaries blur between now and then as Flood plays both the inquiring narrator and a young version of her mother in the past. The women Wohl assembles in a suburban gymnasium might seem like a formulaic bunch were it not for the uniformly dynamite cast, directed with elegant precision by Whitney White. (Following her work on “Jaja’s African Hair Braiding,” White is becoming Broadway’s preeminent interpreter of women-driven ensembles.) They occupy social positions and express various points of view relevant to the movement: There’s a radical Italian immigrant (Irene Sofia Lucio) in need of a green card. An aspiring professional (Audrey Corsa) resisting a mother-approved marriage while facing gender discrimination at work. A longtime housewife (Betsy Aidem) resentful of her ungrateful husband. A broke lesbian (Adina Verson) living out of her car with a pet bird. Each one is tremendously detailed — the earthy, ’70s-chic costumes by Qween Jean and hair and wig design by Nikiya Mathis are indispensable in this regard. Still, as issue plays go, “Liberation” wears no disguises: It’s an effort to engage with social history through messy but representative characters. The women, who attend the group over several years, illustrate the aims of second-wave feminism — the right to self-determination via reproductive freedoms, financial independence and more — on a personal scale. (There’s a man, too, played by Charlie Thurston, whose entrance late in the first act nearly comes as a shock.) Wohl also includes Black characters who indicate the movement’s limitations around accounting for race and other measures of difference. Kristolyn Lloyd plays a budding scholar from New York, in town to care for her ailing mother, while Kayla Davion plays a mom of four boys who comes in searching for a lost backpack. (No wonder the group doesn’t include any young mothers like her, she notes — it meets at 6 p.m. on a school night.) Both actors are exceptional and are given an opportunity to step back from the story and comment on their place in it, a self-conscious nod to Wohl’s position as a White writer. “Stick to what you know,” Lloyd tells the narrator, after a standout scene that finds the two Black women toying with kinship before starkly disagreeing on a central question: Can a movement focused on and led by White women ever square with the struggle for Black civil rights? The play is full of discursive moments like these — impasses, tangents and pivots when its investigation of the past isn’t sure where to go next. The championship flags and scoreboard mounted on the back wall, indications of victories achieved in linear fashion, are a clever bit of visual irony (the set is by David Zinn and the time-warpy lighting is by Cha See). The reality that progress isn’t straightforward or guaranteed is a lesson every generation has to learn through experience. In that way, the narrator isn’t a stand-in just for the playwright, but for anyone trying to figure out how we got here. By framing “Liberation” as a personal quest for one daughter to understand her mom, Wohl also makes a powerful point about the legacy of social movements. For as many books are pulled from libraries or paintings put into storage, there are exponentially more people with firsthand stories to share about their own pursuit of freedom. We can always choose to turn to each other and listen. Liberation, through Jan. 11 at the James Earl Jones Theatre in New York. 2 hours and 30 minutes with an intermission. liberationbway.com.

llmScore.reasoning: [two-model-fallback] | Bucket disagreement: claude=Rave, gemini=Positive | Claude: The Washington Post explicitly calls it 'an extraordinary must-see' and praises it as more than ameliorative, highlighting vibrant complex characters. The aggregator context shows overwhelmingly positive critical consensus with an 89.3% average rating. | Gemini: The review excerpt indicates a positive assessment, highlighting the play's appeal and the complexity of its characters, suggesting a recommendation with some reservations.

bwwExcerpt: But “Liberation” does more than appeal to resistance-frazzled nerves, an ameliorative quality it shares with last season’s “Good Night, and Good Luck,” the hit George Clooney vehicle about a free press holding the government to account. Wohl’s ensemble drama is a memory play about a social movement, full of arguments that will ring familiar to many. But it’s rooted in vibrant, complex characters who embody the individual stakes entangled behind efforts at solidarity. Average Rating: 89.3% { "@context":"https://schema.org", "@type":"LiveBlogPosting", "@id":"/article/Review-Roundup-LIBERATION-Opens-On-Broadway-20251028", "about":{ "@type":"Event", "startDate":"2025-10-28T10:07:39-05:00", "name":"Review Roundup: Bess Wohl's LIBERATION Opens On Broadway", "eventAttendanceMode": "https://schema.org/OnlineEventAttendanceMode", "location": { "@type": "VirtualLocation", "url": "/article/Review-Roundup-LIBERATION-Opens-On-Broadway-20251028" } }, "coverageStartTime":"2025-10-28T10:07:39-05:00", "coverageEndTime":"2025-10-29T01:07:39-05:00", "headline":"Review Roundup: Bess Wohl's LIBERATION Opens On Broadway", "description":"See what the critics are saying about Liberation, the new play by Tony Award nominee Bess Wohl. The play examines a meeting between a group of women at the height of the women's liberation movement of the 1970s.", "liveBlogUpdate":[ { "@type":"BlogPosting", "headline":"The New York Times - ‘Liberation’ Review: A Tony-Worthy Ensemble Plotting Revolution", "datePublished":"2025-10-29T09:02:05-05:00", "articleBody": "By no means do I want to give the impression that “Liberation” is the kind of good-for-you didactic show that feels like an assignment. Not only does its sustained pace make the story downright suspenseful — we quickly become invested in these women and wonder what will become of them — but spending time in their company is also an unadulterated pleasure. Directed with sensitivity by Whitney White and performed by a cast preternaturally in sync, the production looks at community and individuality, determination and self-determination, in an elegiac and impassioned manner." }, { "@type":"BlogPosting", "headline":"Vulture - Re-Encountering Liberation on Broadway", "datePublished":"2025-10-29T09:02:05-05:00", "articleBody": "Both times I’ve seen the play—Off Broadway this spring, now returning in a larger space on Broadway—I’ve felt unprepared for the emotional wallop it lands, the way that Wohl’s work becomes cosmically immense without leaving that gym basement. I think it gets there by staying so focused on the quietly radical thing these women are doing with each other, and which Wohl is making the rest of the audience engage in. Maybe you should be scared, because listening could change you too." }, { "@type":"BlogPosting", "headline":"Variety - ‘Liberation’ Broadway Review: An Impressive Memory Play That Delivers a Fresh and Frank Take on the Women’s Rights Movement ", "datePublished":"2025-10-29T09:02:05-05:00", "articleBody": "It can be challenging to deliver something fresh and unique to the memory play genre. However, in writer Bess Wohl‘s new Broadway show, “Liberation,” she manages to do just that. " }, { "@type":"BlogPosting", "headline":"Time Out New York - Liberation", "datePublished":"2025-10-29T09:02:05-05:00", "articleBody": "Five stars. Bess Wohl's feminist drama keeps the conversation going. " }, { "@type":"BlogPosting", "headline":"The Wrap - It was great Off Broadway. Now Bess Wohl’s play comes to Broadway where it continues to ask: What the hell went wrong?", "datePublished":"2025-10-29T09:02:05-05:00", "articleBody": "When Bess Wohl’s “Liberation” opened Off Broadway all the way back in February, it would have been ridiculous to grace it with best-of superlatives. Now that “Liberation” has opened on Broadway this Tuesday at the James Earl Jones Theatre, it’s entirely apt to write that it’s the year’s best play. There are only a few other new plays to open in 2025 and I’ve seen most of them in previews. Bank on it: “Liberation” remains the best." }, { "@type":"BlogPosting", "headline":"Entertainment Weekly - Liberation review: Bess Wohl's new Broadway play highlights how the times, they aren't a-changin'", "datePublished":"2025-10-29T09:02:05-05:00", "articleBody": "Liberation may not be able to answer life's difficult questions, but it knows that it's important to foster these conversations and to come together to try our best to make the world a better place — especially when history often seems hellbent on repeating itself. And, four steps out of the theater, it's clear that messaging has hit its mark when a young woman turns to her friend and brightly declares, I'm fired up! Grade: B+ " }, { "@type":"BlogPosting", "headline":"The Daily Beast - The Brilliant ‘Liberation’ Sheds Its Clothes to Get to the Naked Truth", "datePublished":"2025-10-29T09:02:05-05:00", "articleBody": "The play speaks to itself, it speaks to us, and it encourages a dialogue straight back at it. In this sense, it is its own highly effective consciousness-raising exercise, looking at us in our present day where the principles of equality and progress are becoming derided and imperiled. What the women thought they were confronting and vanquishing in the early 1970s remains all too prescient." }, { "@type":"BlogPosting", "headline":"Chicago Tribune - Review: ‘Liberation’ on Broadway is brave enough to ask, what does feminism mean?", "datePublished":"2025-10-29T09:02:05-05:00", "articleBody": "“Liberation” pokes fun at long, “male” plays written by the childless, which is a bit of a cheap shot, albeit one that lands with this audience. In reality, it has much in common with those epic lifts, and that’s a compliment. There are certain thematic interests and structural devices in common with Paula Vogel’s “Mother Play,” which is not surprising, but Wohl has such a powerful and enjoyable voice. She makes everyone care about the questions she has herself and that’s exactly what a playwright should be doing." }, { "@type":"BlogPosting", "headline":"The Guardian - Liberation review – fiery and funny show brings 70s feminism to Broadway", "datePublished":"2025-10-29T09:02:05-05:00", "articleBody": "Any listlessness, however, is expelled by the far superior second act, which boldly opens with a meeting in the nude (full bush, hence no phones), inspired by the real efforts of 70s consciousness groups. (Intimacy director Kelsey Rainwater coordinates a fast-settling normalcy to the proceeding.) The play’s second half unravels the frayed distinctions between then and now, memory and reality, skirting the line of self-awareness without tipping fully into self-importance. (It helps that it’s frequently quite funny, even biting.) " }, { "@type":"BlogPosting", "headline":"amNY - Review | ‘Liberation’ bares all—literally and politically", "datePublished":"2025-10-29T09:02:05-05:00", "articleBody": "In “Liberation,” Bess Wohl’s daring and deeply analytical new play, the act of exposure is both literal and intellectual. Wohl strips away nostalgia and ideology to examine how the 1970s women’s liberation movement reshaped lives, where it fell short, and what its legacy means today. She’s less interested in celebrating the past than in interrogating it—probing questions of identity, sacrifice, and progress with the precision of a social scientist and the empathy of a dramatist. " }, { "@type":"BlogPosting", "headline":"New York Theatre Guide - 'Liberation' review — Bess Wohl's memory play is sharp and witty", "datePublished":"2025-10-29T09:02:05-05:00", "articleBody": "Tackling misogyny, internalized homophobia, domestic abuse, gender roles, and the need for intersectionality, Liberation leaves no stone unturned in its quest for answers about the past and the present. But with any of these topics, no play can have the answers to something that we haven’t figured out yet in real life – and that’s all part of the point. " }, { "@type":"BlogPosting", "headline":"New York Theater - Liberation Broadway Review", "datePublished":"2025-10-29T09:02:05-05:00", "articleBody": "Much of the strength of the production, which has moved intact from its Off-Broadway run earlier this year, resides in the ensemble acting, theater regulars portraying everyday women with grace and good humor. " }, { "@type":"BlogPosting", "headline":"New York Stage Review - Liberation: This Is How We Change the World", "datePublished":"2025-10-29T09:02:05-05:00", "articleBody": "When Bess Wohl’s Liberation began performances off-Broadway at the Roundabout’s Laura Pels Theatre earlier this year, it was just after Trump’s second inauguration. The time-hopping memory play—which looks at a multigenerational group of second-wave feminists through a world-weary modern-day lens—registered as capital-I Important. Though not in a didactic, dullsville way. In a Heidi Chronicles kind of way." }, { "@type":"BlogPosting", "headline":"New York Stage Review - Liberation: The Women Are Back and Better than Ever", "datePublished":"2025-10-29T09:02:05-05:00", "articleBody": "When Bess Wohl’s play Liberation premiered off-Broadway last winter it was revelatory. Despite some structural weaknesses that remain, it’s a beautiful work featuring an ensemble of actors at the top of their game. It’s no wonder the production transferred to Broadway totally intact. " }, { "@type":"BlogPosting", "headline":"Washington Post - Broadway’s new play about the women’s movement is an extraordinary must-see", "datePublished":"2025-10-29T09:02:05-05:00", "articleBody": " But “Liberation” does more than appeal to resistance-frazzled nerves, an ameliorative quality it shares with last season’s “Good Night, and Good Luck,” the hit George Clooney vehicle about a free press holding the government to account. Wohl’s ensemble drama is a memory play about a social movement, full of arguments that will ring familiar to many. But it’s rooted in vibrant, complex characters who embody the individual stakes entangled behind efforts at solidarity." } ] }
